results.title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (Disney)
results.creator_credit: Don Hahn, Walt Disney Pictures, Gary Trousdale and Kirk Wise
results.brief_description: Animated musical Disney version of Victor Hugo’s gothic novel “The Hunchback of Notre Dame.” Quasimodo is a hunchback who was rescued by a kindly priest, just as he was to be cast down a well. Now an adult, Quasimodo is employed as bell ringer at the monastery, but is an outcast and a prisoner in his bell tower, by order of his master Judge Frollo. During a carnival, Quasimodo is taunted by the merciless crowd and about to be flogged when a beautiful and spirited gypsy woman named Esmeralda intervenes. Frollo, a treacherous man who loathes gypsies, falls in lust with Esmeralda, who enrages him further by spurning his advances and mocking him. Esmeralda meanwhile has fallen for the handsome Phoebus, despite feeling compassion for the brutalised Quasimodo. Unlike other Disney productions, “The Hunchback of Notre Dame” entertains darker themes of racism, desire and rebellion, and the animation matches the sinister undercurrents of the book. The animation is impressive, (at times recalling “Fantasia”) as is the voice work of Tom Hulce, Demi Moore and Kevin Kline. Deviating from the original novel, comic relief is provided in the order of numerous gargoyles that befriend Quasimodo.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Hahn, Walt Disney Pictures, Gary Trousdale and Kirk Wise

results.title: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame = Notre Dame de Paris
results.creator_credit: Cocinor, Allied Artists Pictures, Robert Edmonds, Betty Edmonds, Raymond Hakim and Jean Delannoy
results.brief_description: Anthony Quinn plays the deformed hunchbacked bell-ringer Quasimodo and Gina Lollobrigida stars as the beautiful gypsy dancing girl Esmeralda in this French/Italian adaptation of Victor Hugo’s all-time classic novel about friendship, love and loyalty. Lavish sets, costume and make-up, along with a cast of thousands, are used to create a historical epic in the style of such films as “The Ten commandments” and “Ben Hur”, but unfortunately does not quite succeed in the same way that these films did. The dialogue at times is perhaps overdone and the film comes across more as a theatrical presentation, lacking a sense of realism. However this is not to take away from Anthony Quinn and Gina Lollobrigida’s solid performances in their respective roles. Cast also includes Alaine Cuny, Jean Danet, Robert Hirsch, Danielle Dumont, Philippe Clay. NOTE: This film is partially dubbed.

results.title: The Hume highway
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the road link between Melbourne and Sydney, showing the many places of interest along the Hume Highway. Describes the early explorations of Hume and Hovell in 1824; the founding of Melbourne in 1835; travel by coach in the gold rush days; the building of the first railway lines; the introduction of the first internal combustion engines leading to a great increase in mechanical road transportation and the building of the Hume Highway. The latter part of the film shows various places of interest along the Highway between Melbourne and Albury. Commentary by Walter Pym. Photography by J. B. Stirling.

results.title: The Humble force
results.creator_credit: John Maynard, Geoff Steven, New Zealand National Film Unit and Phase Three Films
results.brief_description: Beyond the Great Wall of China lies “the power of the ancient dynasties and the new red star of communism”. This film explores the juxtaposition of China’s ancient heritage with its continuing advances into technology, communism and subtle trends into westernisation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Maynard, Geoff Steven, New Zealand National Film Unit and Phase Three Films

results.title: The Human skeleton. Part 3. Muscles, movements and pressure
results.creator_credit: Frank Wells, Gaumont-British Instructional and Beryl Denman Lacey
results.brief_description: Shows the workings of muscles and tendons within the human skeletal structure, with main emphasis on the diaphragm and the muscles required to maintain a human in an erect position.
results.title_for_label: The Human skeleton. Part 3. Muscles, movements and pressure

results.title: The Human skeleton. Part 2. Muscles, movement and posture
results.creator_credit: Frank Wells, Gaumont-British Instructional and Beryl Denman Lacey
results.brief_description: Shows by live-action, animated diagram and radiology, the position, attachment, and function of the muscles relative to the bones and joints; the movements of the arm and of respiration; and the action of the muscles in maintaining posture in the standing and moving positions.

results.title: The Human nervous system
results.creator_credit: Robert Churchill, Churchill Films and John McDonald
results.brief_description: Shows the differences and similarities between simple animals and humans to explain the role of the nervous system. Also studies the structure of the brain and its complexity. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Human machine
results.brief_description: Looks at the problems which confront people with physical disabilities and the ways modern technology can help them. Shows research and production of artificial limbs, the manner in which people with limited movements can become mobile and learn to communicate. Presented by James Dibble. Suitable for secondary level.
